author: Lee Boyce for Thisismoney.co.uk
title: Atom launches new one-year fixed-rate savings paying 2%
text:
Put-upon British savers have been thrown a lifeline with the surprise launch of a one-year account paying 2 per cent today.
Beating the current top-paying one-year bond by 0.4 percentage points, Atom Bank has sent ripples through the savings market and provided an account which currently beats inflation.
It is the first one-year deal to pay two per cent since April 2016, but it remains to be seen whether it will spark a revival in the moribund deposit account market.
Bumper rates: Atom Bank has blown away the competition with its new range of fixed-rate savings deals
The new rate is a 0.5 percentage points hike on what it offered previously and shows a clean pair of heels to nearest rival Charter Savings Bank, which offers 1.6 per cent over the same period, into the shade.
It means that savers can beat current inflation with the 12-month fix, which was recorded at 1.8 per cent in January 2017 - although inflation is predicted to rise over the course of the year.
HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP Can you find a better deal?: Fixed-rate savings accounts best buy tables Furthermore, it is upping its two-year deal from 1.65 per cent to 2.1 per cent again replacing Charter as a best buy, which offers 1.75 per cent.
Charter only launched this best buy range of fixed-rate savings accounts last week.
The scrap to top the independent This is Money savings table does not stop there.
A new three-year deal offers 2.2 per cent, up from 1.75 per cent, while its five-year fix has risen from 2.05 per cent to 2.4 per cent.
Again, this completely annihilates the competition as Atom makes a bold move which may mean other competitors need to follow suit in order to attract funds.
BEST RATES FOR A WHILE According to Moneyfacts, these are the best rates since last summer.
- The last time a one-year fix paid two per cent was in April 2016, when Union Bank of India paid 2.15 per cent.
- Last time a two-year fix paid 2.10 per cent was July 2016, when Fidor Bank paid 2.20 per cent.
- Three-year fix paid 2.2 per cent was in July 2016 when FIdor Bank paid 2.45 per cent.
- Five-year fix paid 2.4 per cent was July 2016 when Milestone Savings paid 2.50 per cent.
The accounts offer an option for savers to take the interest monthly.
They can only be opened via its app, which is offered by the Apple and Google stores.
Once savers have downloaded the app, they need to register and verify their identity.
Durham-based Atom Bank launched last year with a number of savings rates.
There are also rumours circulating this week that US pop star Will.i.am is about to own a share of it and sit on the board.
It is yet to offer current accounts, but these will be coming in the near future.
Its chairman is Anthony Thomson, one of the founders of Metro Bank and its chief executive is Mark Mullen, who formerly worked at First Direct.
He revealed in December that its fixed-rate savings accounts had attracted £110million. It is backed by a number of investors, including fund manager Neil Woodford.
Savings are protected under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme to the tune of £85,000, or £170,000 for joint accounts.
Celebrity: According to rumours, pop star Will.i.am may be a shareholder in the bank and could sit on the board
But many may be scratching their heads at just why Atom Bank has acted so aggressively with the rates.
In an e-mail received on Wednesday 22 February morning, Atom told This is Money it was moving its one-year fix up to a best buy, but to a slimmer 1.7 per cent.
Its two-year was moving up to 1.8 per cent, three-year to 1.9 per cent and five-year to 2.3 per cent.
By the evening, it had changed its tune – and revealed it was offering the bumper rates by the standards of current conditions, in what it described as 'amazing news for customers'.
Good rates: So, why is the Durham based bank offering such bumper rates? It says its cost efficient compared to rivals
A spokesman for Atom added: 'Our savings are distributed through the Atom Banking app. We don't have branches, we don't have big call centres, we don't have desktop browser services.
'This single-minded approach means that we are taking the cost, the complexity and the inefficiency out of banking.
'We intend to share the benefits of doing so with our customers and we are only just getting started. We're here to disrupt, and that's exactly what we're doing.
'With regard to rate availability, just like the rest of the market, we can't guarantee our rates for a certain period of time, but we are committed to making things better for our customers and will be doing our best to remain competitive.'
James Blower, independent expert at The Savings Guru and former head of a number of challenger banks, said: 'These rates are great for savers.
'So why are Atom paying so much? It needs savers money to lend out to customers of their newly launched mortgage business. This has some very attractive rates on offer so I expect they are seeing good demand.
'However, in late December, Atom announced that they had raised £110million of savings on their fixed deposits. This is not very much in eight months in a savings market worth over £1.4 trillion and is a fraction of what other new banks have raised.
'So, have they been struggling to raise deposits compared to others? It certainly looks like it. They have also offered pretty competitive rates previously - so rates are unlikely to be issue.
'A look at the reviews for the bank show a really mixed bag. Atom has been a bit marmite with most people either loving it or hating it and going elsewhere.
'There are suggestions there has been problems with the app and also that the operational support, if customers need to communicate away from the app, isn't so strong. So this could well be deterring savers.
'Savers can only apply for fixed deposits via the Atom app. The app also requires the use of things like selfies for security. While these are the sort of features that young millennials love, the average saver is usually in their late 60s.
'This customer typically might be happy to research online via a phone or tablet but will apply for an account via a desktop PC or post/phone.
'Atom may have realised this and are possibly over paying on rates to compensate and encourage savers to preserve. If that's the case, I hope they have also enhanced their customer support to cope with the influx of enquiries they will inevitably get with these rates.
'In summary, this is great news for savers who are happy to get to grips with the Atom app, but I'm not sure I'd be so happy if I was an investor in the Bank seeing savings rates being offered well over market rates and also more than those being paid by some of its mortgage customers.'
Charlotte Nelson, of independent comparison website Moneyfacts, adds: 'It's fantastic to see positive movement in the savings market. These new rates from Atom Bank will make their mark on the best buys.
'However, with these deals operated by mobile app only some savers may be put off.
'Competition amongst the challenger banks has started to hot up of the past few weeks. Many savers will be wary of these unknown brands but with protection schemes in places there is little to worry about.'
